item.title: Joseph Nathan Cohen
item.description:
Facebook reportedly turned over chat messages between mother and daughter, leading to charges of abortion-related felonies. You all think you'll be able to just go to another state or Canada, but don't be so sure. Your phone knows everything, and tech will snitch.
https://www.theverge.com/2022/8/10/23299502/facebook-chat-messenger-history-nebraska-teen-abortion-case

item.title: Thiago Carvalho
item.description: "There were, however, times when the biological sciences were not yet domesticated and did not march nicely in pairs on the leash of chemistry."- Erwin Chargaffhttps://www.queensu.ca/academia/forsdyke/bioinfo1.htm

item.title: Armin Lak
item.description: One of the first (or the first if I am not mistaken) who recorded brain's dopamine and serotonin neurons. Several foundational works. RIP Geroge Aghajanian. https://medicine.yale.edu/psychiatry/news-article/in-memoriam-george-k-aghajanian-md/

item.title: Theresa Desrochers
item.description: ‚ÄúIt is within my brain, then, in the wonderful neurons which make up the gray cortex of the cerebrum, that I not only think but feel.‚Äù - Frances Gulick Jewett, from Control of Body and Mind, 1908. #neuroscience

item.title: Tim Hanson
item.description: https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11644 Textbooks are all you needDemonstrates that by training on a high-quality yet small dataset (7B tokens, 7 epochs), a small network (1.3B parameters) can beat almost all models in Python coding (except for GPT-4, which has 1.7T parameters.)The model was trained for 4 days on 8 GPUs, orders of magnitude less than lower-performing models. (Environmentalists, rejoice!)

item.description: Amazingly, I made this several years ago

item.title: MurmeltHier
item.description:
WAIT WHAT?!
We are capable of pulling energy straight out of (humid) thin air now?! ü§Ø "‚ÄúTo be frank, it was an accident,‚Äù says the study‚Äôs lead author, Prof Jun Yao. ‚ÄúWe were actually interested in making a simple sensor for humidity in the air. But for whatever reason, the student who was working on that forgot to plug in the power.‚ÄùThe UMass Amherst team were surprised to find that the device, which comprised an array of microscopic tubes, or nanowires, was producing an electrical signal regardless.(...)However, 20,000 of them stacked into a washing machine-sized cube, they say, could generate 10 kilowatt hours of energy a day ‚Äì roughly the consumption of an average UK household. Even more impressive: they plan to have a prototype ready for demonstration in 2024."https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/jul/02/it-was-an-accident-the-scientists-who-have-turned-humid-air-into-renewable-power#Energy #ClimateSolutions #Renewable

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: @schoppik Sorry. At first I was surprised that Polestar doesn‚Äôt use runflats https://www.polestar.com/en-sg/polestar-2/extras/wheels/ but then I saw the sidewall damage‚Äî whatever happened would have destroyed any tire. I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre safe.

item.title: Matej Kohar
item.description:
CFP: Berlin Workshop on Neuroscientific Explanation (12th-13th October)Consider submitting an abstract and joining us at the TU Berlin if you are interested in the philosophical questions connected with the nature of explanation in #neuroscience. Deadline: 6th August.Keynote speakers:
Galia Avidan (University of the Negev)
Nir Fresco (University of the Negev)
Friedemann Pulverm√ºller (FU Berlin)
Peter Schulte (Uni Z√ºrich)More info: https://www.tu.berlin/philkognition/events/neuroexp-2023#philosophy @philosophy

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: A camera sensor with 58.6 square CENTIMETERS of detector area. Opens up more parameter space for imaging systems. Noise characteristic probably aren't amazing, but that can be okay in some applications. ... and that front wide-angle lens! http://labrigger.com/blog/2023/07/09/new-camera-316-mpixel-58-6-square-cm/

item.title: Neuromatch
item.description: We had our opening ceremonies yesterday and our courses #ComputationalNeuroscience and #DeepLearning for 2023 have officially launched! ü•≥‚ÄãStudents and TAs across the Asia-Pacific üåè‚Äã and Europe-Africa üåç‚Äã time zones are already meeting on either Zoom or our self-hosted instances of BigBlueButton! Later in the day, we'll also be welcoming our students from the Americas zones üåé‚ÄãOur discord servers are buzzing with activity and students are hanging out together for peer-programming sessions üíª‚ÄãWe have some fun contests and professional development activities planned. Stay tuned!#neuromatch #neuromatchstodon #NeuromatchAcademy @neuromatch@a.gup.pe #neuroscience

item.title: Kristin Branson
item.description:
For the Cajal summer school on Machine Learning for Neuroscience, I gave this presentation yesterday on trends in #ML from 2000-present. I had lots of fun making these slides -- it was nice to get to talk about ML from the '00s (all this knowledge stored in my brain that never gets to come out!) and what I thought were the important trends of the past quarter century.
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/17b6xzZXQKMRyvWX5DGD6WyPWnk-NSzE4OiRrmJb_gg0/edit?usp=sharing

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
If the neurons are musicians in an orchestra, the brain regions are their sections, and the memory is the music they produce, the study‚Äôs authors said, then the electric field is the conductor.Brain networks encoding memory come together via electric fields, study finds.
https://picower.mit.edu/news/brain-networks-encoding-memory-come-together-electric-fields-study-finds

item.title: Robert Reich
item.description: The upward redistribution of wealth over the past 45 years has shifted $50 trillion from the bottom 90% to the top 1%. That‚Äôs $50 trillion that would have gone into the paychecks of working Americans.The wealth doesn‚Äôt ‚Äútrickle down.‚Äù It gushes up.
